loans.name: Janchiv

texts.en:
Janchiv is 27 years old and lives with his wife and a daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Janchiv and his family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent, on a plot of land with a yard that belongs to his sister. Janchiv's wife is a very supportive person for him and his business. 

Janchiv attended training in carpentry in 2007, and after he finished the course he started his own business with a working capital of 100,000 tugrugs (~ 70 USD). After 3 years of hard work, his working capital has grown to 500,000 tugrugs (~ 351 USD). 

Janchiv has been using his father-in-law's workplace and tools to manufacture wooden products. He has great communication skills and says, “I would like to produce high quality and finely crafted products for my customers.” He is requesting a 350,000 tugrugs (~ 246 USD) loan to purchase materials to manufacture wooden furniture and parts for a 'ger' (the Mongolian nomadic tent).

loans.use: To purchase wooden planks

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri sont majoritairement mariées, ont en moyenne 42 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Kantela relevant  de Massigui, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième  région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font  essentiellement l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires et  des céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursé leur premier prêt, les femmes du groupe Tiessiri  sont à leur  2  prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce  prêt pour acheter, 3 tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, fonio, riz) et  une grande quantité  de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs de céréales et grossistes de condiments au marché hebdomadaire de Massigui et effectuent leurs ventes  sur place au marché de Massigui et à Kantela à domicile, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
The women of the group Tiessiri are mostly married, they have an average age of 42, with 5 children each on average and they all live in traditional extended families in the town of Kantela, close to Massigui, in the county of Dioila, the second administrative region of the republic of Mali. These woman know each other through neighborhood conenctions and family ties. Their business is essentially the sale of condiments and grains/ cereals. Having properly repaid their first loan, the women of the group Tiessiri are on their second group loan. They will use this loan to purchase 3 tons of cereals (beans, millet, corn, fonio (a millet-like grain) and rice), and a large quantity of condiments. They mostly supply themselves locally with the cereal farmers and condiment wholesalers in Massigui's weekly market. They sell their goods in the marketplace of Massigui and in Kantela from their homes, for cash and credit to a clientele composed of men and women. They envision each earning a monthly income of 15,000 FCFA, which they will use to reinforce their business' funds and provide for their food expenses, their children's tuition and for their healthcare costs.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase general food products

loans.name: Omowumi

texts.en:
Omowumi is 32 years old and married with a child. Her child is 8 years old and attends school. Her husband sells chemicals to support their home. She is a happy and hard-working woman. 

Omowumi has a stall in Ibadan where she sells colorful ladies' shoes and bags at retail prices. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more ladies' shoes and bags to sell. She hopes to own a shoe factory in the future. She sells for long hours to enable her to help her husband support the family. She duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more ladies' bags and shoes to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a single lady who lives and operates her business in Machakos.  She operates a retail shop selling sugar, cooking fat, salt, soap, flour, rice etc. She has been in this business for two years.  She hopes to own a wholesale shop and a supermarket in future.  She also dreams of buying a plot of land and a vehicle in future.  She has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add more stock to her inventory.  She describes herself as hard-working and sociable.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 48 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Baba relevant  de Massigui, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième  région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font  essentiellement l’achat vente de céréales et de la restauration.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Benkadi  sont à leur  4 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 2 tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, riz) et  une importante quantité d’ingrédients pour la restauration. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs de céréales et grossistes pour les ingrédients rentrant dans la restauration au marché hebdomadaire de Massigui et effectuent leurs ventes  sur place au marché de Massigui et à Baba à domicile, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
The women of the group Benkadi are all married. On average, they are 48 years old, with 4 children each and live in traditional extended families in the town of Baba, close to Massigui, in the county of Dioila, the second adminstrative region of the republic of Mali. These women know each other through neighborhood connections and family ties. Their business is basically the sale of cereals/ grains and restaurants. Having properly repaid their 3 previous loans, the women of the group Benkadi are on their 4 group loan. They will use this loan to purchase 2 tons of cereals (beans, millet, corn and rice) and a large quantity of the ingredients needed for their restaurant business. They supply themselves mostly locally from the cereal farmers and buying the ingredients for their restaurant business from wholesalers, and from the weekly market in Massigui. They sell their goods in the market of Massigui and in Baba from their homes, for cash and credit to a clientele composed of men and women. They envision each earning a monthly income of 10,000FCFA, which they will use to strengthen their business' funds and to pay for their expenses, such as food, their children's tuition, and healthcare costs.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase general food products

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth J. is currently in the business of selling  groundnut paste at home and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell.  Elizabeth is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bags of groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is 28 years old and married with one child who attends school.  He has been in the welding business for six years; he makes metal doors, gates, windows and does general welding.  He earns extra income from a tailoring business.  He dreams of owning plots of land and building residential and commercial houses.  He also dreams of owning a vehicle and a motorcycle in future.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy a mill for grinding grain and purchase welding materials.  He describes himself as hard-working.

loans.use: Buy a mill for grinding grain and welding materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Danaya sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Baba relevant  de Massigui, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième  région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font  essentiellement l’achat vente de céréales, la prestation de service (tailleur) et de la restauration.
Ces femmes du groupe  Danaya de l’association Djiguiya  sont à leur  premier prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 2 tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, riz) et  une importante quantité d’ingrédients pour la restauration. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs de céréales et grossistes pour les ingrédients rentrant dans la restauration au marché hebdomadaire de Massigui et effectuent leurs ventes  sur place au marché de Massigui et à Baba à domicile, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
The women of the group Danaya are all married. On average, they are 40 years old, each have 3 children and they all live in traditional extended families in the town of Baba, close to Massigui, in the county of Dioila, the second administrative region of the republic of Mali. These women know each other through neighborhood connections and family ties. Their basic businesses are the sale of cereals/ grains, offering a service (tailoring) and restaurants. The women of the group Danaya of the association Djiguiya are taking their first group loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They intend to use this loan to purchase 2 tons of cereals (beans, corn, rice) and a large quantity of the ingredients need for their restaurant business. They supply themselves mostly locally from cereal producers and from wholesalers in the weekly market in Massigui for the ingredients for their restaurant business. They sell their goods in the market of Massigui and in Baba from their homes, for cash and credit to a clientele composed of men and women. They envision earning a monthly income of 10,000FCFA, which they will use to strengthen their business' funds and to take care of their expenses for food, their children's tuition and healthcare costs. Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase general food products

loans.name: Jennelyn

texts.en:
Jennelyn B., 42, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Ruben B., a taxi driver, she is blessed in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn a living so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store while being a rice dealer.

Jennelyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 11,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying stocks needed to replenish her current product inventory. She is also investing some of the loan in her rice business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying stocks needed to replenish her current product inventory and rice for resale

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy W. M. is thirty-five years old, married, and has three children aged between sixteen and eight years old. Her business is located at Lang'ta, Nairobi near a chief's canteen. She has been selling food, e.g., pilau (rice), posho (maize meal), chicken, tea, soft drinks, and other items for the last four years to the local people. 

Nancy says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is power fluctuations, reducing quality service delivery. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes. 50,000 to buy fruit, a blender and a microwave to expand her business. She hopes to grow hier restaurant to a big hotel in future. She is very hard-working, honest, reliable and trustworthy.

loans.use: Microwave, blender, fruit

loans.name: Yeson-Erdene

texts.en:
Yeson-Erdene is 38 years old and lives with her husband and their two children in Tuv province, Mongolia.  Her daughter lives at home and does not attend kindergarten. They  have been living in their current home for 20 years. She has been operating a small food shop near the local secondary school since 2000. 

Since they started the business, their standard of living has improved. Yeson-Erdene has great business experience that she gained in previous years. She is a very hard-working and honest person. Yeson-Erdene would like to expand her small food shop into a bigger  food  shop with a greater variety of products. Yeson-Erdene is requesting a 1,300,000 tugrug (~ 914 USD) loan to increase her working capital and to purchase a variety of products for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more products for her grocery store

loans.name: Senan

texts.en: This young man is single. Senan was born in 1989. He teaches students to play the accordion. Senan has been in this business for 2 years. He lives in Baku city. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to improve his business.

loans.use: to improve his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and resell coffee

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith I., 41, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Alexander and they are blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her variety store for one year now.

Edith has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

Now, with your help, Edith would like to obtain a PHP 9,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying stock needed to replenish her current inventory.

Edith dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also works hard so that her family can have a good and peaceful life.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy stock needed to replenish her inventory

loans.name: Inoviva

texts.en:
Inoviva M., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Rolando M., a salesman, they are blessed with six children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been raising hogs with the help of her family for the last fourteen years.

Inoviva has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her hog-raising business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 9,000 lPHP oan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more piglets to be raised for meat.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more piglets to be raised for meat

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Benkola sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Sounkoro relevant  de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, deuxième  région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font  essentiellement l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires et  des céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Benkola  sont à leur  4 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 1 tonne de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, fonio, riz) et  une importante quantité  de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs de céréales et grossistes de condiments au marché hebdomadaire de Massigui et effectuent leurs ventes  sur place au marché de Massigui et à Sounkoro à domicile, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 8.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
The ten women of the group Benkola are all married. On average they are each 40 years old, each have 4 children and all live in traditional extended families in the town of Sounkoro, close to Massigui, in the county of Dioïla, the second administrative region of the republic of Mali. These women know each other through neighborhood connections and family ties. Their business is basically the sale of food condiments and cereals/ grains. Having fully repaid their three previous loans, the women of the group Benkola are on their fourth group loan. They will use this loan to purchase 1 ton of cereals (beans, millet, corn, fonio (a millet-like grain) and rice), and a large quantity of condiments. They supply themselves mostly from local grain producers and purchase the condiments from wholesalers in the weekly market of Massigui. They sell their goods in the marketplace of Massigui and also in Sounkoro from their homes. They sell for cash and credit, to a clientele composed of men and women. They envision each earning a monthly income of 8,000FCFA, which they will use to reinforce their business' funds and to take care of their family's food expenses, their children's tuition, and healthcare costs.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Javzan

texts.en: Javzan is 36 years old and lives with her husband and son in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. In 2007, she started her tire repair business with her husband. Currently she has working capital of 1,350,000 MNT ($950). Javzan has been renting  space that belongs to one of her relatives for her business.  She says, “I would like to purchase my own plot of land with a yard and a ger." She is requesting a 580,000 MNT ($408) loan to purchase additional materials for the tire repair business.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for the tire repair business.

loans.name: Jo-Ane

texts.en:
Jo-Ane S., 38, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Marzan, a painter, they are blessed with one child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been operating three businesses at once, direct selling of cosmetics, selling ready-to-wear clothing and selling frozen cuts of meat and cured hams.

Jo-Ane has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 27,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding businesses by buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her inventories.

She dreams that her businesses will continue to grow so that she can provide for her family’s everyday needs. She also wishes that her whole family will have good health.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products to be incorporated into her inventories.

loans.name: Meshack

texts.en:
Meshack S. N. is thirty-two years old, married and has three children between the ages of eight and one year old. His business is located at Jambo-Chaani, an industrial area in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian ocean white beaches. 

He has been selling shoes for the last eleven years to the local people and tourists. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is that shoes for resale are hard to get. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. Meshack is using his loan of 40,000 KES to buy more shoes to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He also hopes to build his own house some day. He is a very hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Regzenlham

texts.en:
Regzenlham is 55 years old and lives with her daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her daughter live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. In 2005 Regzenlham started a cosmetic products trading business. In addition, she has been operating a construction material trading business since 1997, which has a working capital of 1,000,000 MNT ($703). She operates both businesses because her construction material business is seasonal. As a result of her hard work, the working capital of her cosmetics business has grown to 3,000,000 MNT ($2111). 

Regzenlham is a very hardworking person and has great communication skills. She likes to quote the Mongolian saying, “Right-mind, Right-action”. She is requesting a 200,000 MNT ($140) loan to purchase a variety of products at wholesale prices and sell them for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products at wholesale prices

loans.name: Ambignakola Group

texts.fr:
Les   femmes du groupe  Ambignakola ont en moyenne  39 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles à Zanfina un des villages  de Fana, préfecture de Dioïla, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et font  l’achat vente, du bois de chauffe, de condiments alimentaires et de céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Ambignakola sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 tonnes de céréales et des colis de plusieurs variétés de condiments alimentaires.
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes d’une façon ambulante et au marché de Fana, généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui servira à essentiellement étoffer leur fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group Ambignakola are, on average, 39 years old, with 4 children each and they all live in traditional families in Zafina, one of the towns of Fana, which is a county of Dioïla, the second administrative region of the republic of Mali. These women know one another through neighborhood connections. They sell firewood, food condiments and cereals/ grains. Having fully repaid 4 previous loans, the women of the group Ambignakola are requesting their fifth group loan, which they will use to purchase 2 tons of cereals/ grains and packages of several varieties of condiments. They supply themselves mostly locally from farmers and wholesalers. They do their sales as they walk around town and also in the market of Fana, usually for cash, to a clientele composed of women and men. They envision each earning an average monthly income of 15,000FCFA, which they will use to reinforce their business' funds.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Carol

texts.en: Carol is an aged woman. She is 58 years old and married with seven children. Carol is not only a wife and mother, she is also a grandmother, and this makes her happy and proud of her grandchildren. She sells colorful sarongs to make a living in Benin City. She loves her work because of the interaction she has with her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience to attract and retain more customers to her business, which she hopes to continue to expand. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora C., 54, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Nelson C., a taxi driver, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been making round rugs for the past four years.

Leonora has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 12 times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her rug-making business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 31,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying a ton of fabric to be used for making the round rugs.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her family’s everyday needs and be able to help others around her.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying a ton of fabric to be used for making round rugs.

loans.name: Busajja Bwakuba Nakimuli Halima Group

texts.en: N. Halima is the group representative of her group. She is married with two children and she has one dependent going to school. She has been dealing in a charcoal business for over three years. With this loan she is purchasing seven bags of charcoal, when previously the maximum she could purchase was four bags. The loan will seriously improve her business as well expanding it. She is a promising businesswoman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase seven bags of charcoal to resell.

loans.name: Nadir

texts.en: Nadir is 39 years old. He is married and has two children. His family lives in the Fuzuli region. He has been in business for five years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy more furniture for expanding his business.

loans.use: to buy furniture

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a 45-year-old woman, married with four children. She sells groceries like tinned milk, tea, washing soap, chocolates, bottled water and more. She has been in this business for over ten years and has been doing well. She supports her husband in taking care of the home and also assists in paying her children’s school fees. 

Maria is asking for a loan of 140,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She said increasing the size of her business, which means stocking her shop with more goods, will attract more customers, more sales and increase her profit as well. She sends a big thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene W. M. is 64, married with six children aged between 40 and 23. Her business is in Kianjao, near Kianjao primary school, in Thika, Kenya. (Thika is the region of Kenya known for the production of pineapples.) She has been selling such items as flour, cooking oil, sugar, tea, bread, milk, salt, etc. to the local people for the past ten years. She says that this business is profitable but her major challenge is customers who are not keen to pay the money on time. However she works very hard to keep her business going and will use her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more flour and sugar to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future. She is very hardworking and cheerful.

loans.use: Buy flour and sugar to sell

loans.name: Busajjja Bwakuba 3 Asina Nalubega Group

texts.en: Asina N. is a hardworking business lady of twenty-seven, married with four children, two of them in school. She also looks after her mother and the father who live with her. She has been running a retail store for over five years. She will use the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, cooking oil, rice, maize flour, etc. She is a determined business lady whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, cooking oil, rice, maize flour, and so forth.

loans.name: Odonchimeg

texts.en: Odonchimeg is 34 years old and lives in Tuv province, Mongolia. She and her daughter live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. They have have lived there for the past five years. During the day, she operates a retail meat business. In 2006, she rented a counter at a local market and started her business with a working capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~ 140 USD). After much hard work her working capital has grown to 2,300,000 tugrugs (~ 1618 USD). With her business profit, she purchased new furniture for her home this year. Odonchimeg pays attention to her daughter's education, and has used her profits to hire a private tutor for her daughter as a supplement to her secondary school lessons. Odonchimeg has great business experience from previous years and has loyal customers. Odonchimeg says: “I would like to expand my business and to purchase an apartment for me and my daughter.” She is requesting a 1,200,000 tugrug (~ 844 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of meat at wholesales price to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of meat at wholesales price

loans.name: Ma. Dolores

texts.en:
Ma. Dolores E., 42, takes care of her family's daily needs. Her husband, Ramil, is a seaman they and they have three children. She has managed a dental clinic for the last fifteen years.

Dolores has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year, regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings, and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her clinic. Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 15,000 loan. This amount will be used to buy equipment and expand her dental clinic. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also dreams that her husband may soon find work.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying equipment and expanding her dental clinic

loans.name: Bayoh

texts.en:
Bayoh M. lives in Freetown, Sierra Leone. He sells drinks and mobile phone top-up cards in a store he rents along a busy road called Kissy Bye Pass road.  Before getting into business, Bayoh worked for the Customs and Excise Department. He is married with three children. His wife is a student in one of the universities in Freetown.

Bayoh intends to buy a generator  for his business and get more stock. He hope to use the proceeds from his loan to pay his wife's university fees and his children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy a generator  and inventory

loans.name: Tumurchudur

texts.en: Tumurchudur is 34 years old and lives with her husband and their three children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family have lived in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, for 6 years. Tumurchudur and her husband have been operating a mobile food trading business out of their  car since 2005. When the business first started their working capital was 400,000 tugrugs (~ 281 USD). However, as a result of their hard work and determination, their working capital has increased to 1,200,000 (~ 844 USD). Since Tumirchudur and her husband started the business their quality of life has improved and they have purchased a new car and are building a house for their family. Tumurchudur and her husband plan to expand their business in the future. Tumurchudur is an open person who has a great communication skills.  She says, “I would like to provide my children with a good education and bring them up them in the proper way.”  She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~ 351 USD) loan to purchase a variety of food products such as flour and rice to resell in the countryside for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food products

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Benkadi  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Zanfina, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes  font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de céréales et de condiments alimentaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, les femmes du groupe  Benkadi sont à leur  deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 3 tonnes de céréales sèches (fonio, petit mil, maïs) et une importante quantité de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes au marché,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Benkadi are all married. On average, they are 35 years old and each have 3 children. They all live in traditional extended families in Zanfina, one of the towns in Fana, a county of Dioila, the second administrative region of Mali. These women mostly buy and sell cereals/ grains, and food condiments. Having fully repaid their first loan, the women of the group Benkadi are requesting their second group loan, which they will use to purchase 3 tons of dried cereals (fonio (a millet-like grain), small millet, corn) and a large quantity of food condiments. They mostly supply themselves locally from farmers and then the women sell their products in the market, usually for cash, to a clientele composed of men and women. They envision each earning an average monthly income of 15,000FCFA, which they will use to pay for the needs of their families and invest the remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cereals and condiments

loans.name: Busajja Bwakuba Alice Wabwire Group

texts.en: Alice W. is a businesswoman of thirty years of age; she is married with six children of whom five are going to school. She has a restaurant and she has been operating this business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase a variety of food (bananas, cassava, Irish potatoes, rice, chicken, beef, and so forth) and other items for the restaurant. She is a hard-working businesswoman who is looking forward to employing other people for the expansion of her restaurant business. Her dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food (bananas, cassava, Irish potatoes, etc.) and other items for the restaurant

loans.name: Dembagnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 femmes du groupe Dembagnouma  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dibida, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe Dembagnouma qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage, font essentiellement l’achat et la vente des articles divers tels les habits les cosmétiques et des  grains de céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les cinq prêts précédents, elles  sont à leur  sixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches (fonio, petit mil, maïs, haricot) estimée à 19 sacs de 100 kg. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement auprès des producteurs du village et environs et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana, à domicile,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes, d’hommes et de revendeurs venant des grandes ville telles  Bamako, Ségou et Koulikoro.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  22.500FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Dembagnouma are all married. On average, they are 37 years old, with four children each and they live in traditional extended families in Dibida, one of the towns of Fana, a county of Dioila, the second administrative region of the republic of Mali. The women of the group Dembagnouma know one another through neighborhood connections. Their business is essentially re-selling various items, such as clothing, cosmetics and cereals/ grains. Having fully repaid their five previous loands, they are requesting their sixth loan, with they will use to purchase a large quantity of dried cereals (fonio (a millet-like grain), small millet, corn and beans) - approximately nineteen 100 kilograms sacks. They mostly supply themselves from farmers in and around their own town. They sell their goods in the market of Fana and from their homes, generally for cash, to a clientele composed of women, men and re-sellers in the large towns of Bamako, Ségou and Koulikoro. They envision each earning an average monthly income of 22,500FCFA, which they will use to pay for the needs of their families and invest the rest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cereals

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en: Rashad was born in 1982. He is married and has a child. Rashad M. and his family live in Baku city. He has been in this business for 5 years. Now Rashad needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy fruits and vegetables for resale to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Luvsanpurev

texts.en:
Luvsanpurev is 22 years old and lives with his mother, brother, and another sibling in Arhangai province, Mongolia.  They live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent.  Her mother is a herder and has a few head of livestock. Luvsanpurev's brother works in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and his sibling is a university student. They have been living in their current home for 22 years.   

Since Luvsanpurev was a child, he helped his father manufacture wooden products. Unfortunately, his father passed away in 2006, and from that time he has worked independently, manufacturing wooden products on his own. Luvsanpurev's family helps him if any help is needed,  and generally the whole family is very supportive of his business. 

He began with a working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~ 35 USD), but with his hard work his working capital has increased to 300,000 tugrugs (~ 211 USD).  Luvsanpurev has been planning to grow his business in the future. He is a very hard-working person and has great communication skills. He says, “I would like to make my mother happier by working hard and continuing to pay for my sibling's university tuition fee.” He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~351 USD) loan to purchase planks for his business.

loans.use: To purchase planks for his business.

loans.name: Elona

texts.en:
41-year-old Elona B. is involved in rice farming. She is married and has four children. She said that her farm really helps her family a lot. But as the needs in her household continue to increase, she tried raising pigs so there would be another source of income for her family. School fees for her children are also a challenge to Elona and her husband, but they are determined to give their children a proper education.

Elona asked for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She said that she would use it to buy farm inputs and also feed for her pigs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Deme Group

texts.fr:
Les 7 femmes du groupe Deme  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans, 5 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dibida, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe Deme qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage, font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de  grains de céréales et de la restauration.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, elles  sont à leur  cinquième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches (petit mil, maïs, niébé, sésame) estimée à 20 sacs de 100 kg. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement auprès des producteurs du village et environs et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana, à domicile,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes, d’hommes et de revendeurs venant des grandes ville telles  Bamako, Ségou et Koulikoro.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  22.500FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven women in the Deme group are all married. They have an average age of 36 years old, an average of five children and they live in large traditional families in Dibida, one of the villages in Fana, in the "prefecture" of Dioila, the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women in the Deme group met through neigbors and primarily buy and sell cereal grains as well as doing some catering. Having repaid four previous loans without incident, they are on their fifth group loan, which will be used to buy a large quantity of dry cereal grains (millet, corn, "niébé" beans, sesame) estimated at around 20 bags of 100kg. They get their supplies primarily from producers in the village and surrounding areas and sell them at the market in Fana and at home, generally for cash to a customer base made up of women, men and retailers coming from large towns such as Bamako, Ségou and Koulikoro. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 22,500 FCFA each, which will be used to provide for the needs of their families; the rest will be invested in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Marife

texts.en: Marife, 35 years old, is a married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has three children with her husband Allan. Her children go to school and it’s a challenge for Marife and her husband to sustain their education. Involved in rice farming, she helps her husband maintain their farm. She makes sure that the farm is free of weeds and pests. Farming is not an easy job for her but she finds it comforting that she and her husband support each other no matter what.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Monita

texts.en: Monita is a mother of three children. She is married and lives with her family in Agusan Del Sur. She joined CEVI a year ago to gain access to its program. She said that her previous loan was really helpful because she was able to supply her farm with seeds, fertilizers, and other inputs. She hopes to grow her farm so she has requested another loan. She is asking for Php 10,000, which she would use to purchase farm inputs. Hopefully, this loan will help Monita achieve her goals.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia has three children with her husband Romeo. She does farming for a living. She and her husband spend the whole day tilling their farm. The rice farm is the only source of income her family has. 

Last year, Sylvia was able to join CEVI, a micro-finance institution (MFI) in the Philippines. She says that her first loan was a big help to her business. She particularly likes the low interest rate offered by the MFI. Now, she requests a loan of Php 11,000. With this amount, Sylvia would be able to acquire seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs her farm lacks.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Djiguignouma Group

texts.fr:
Les 5 femmes du groupe Djiguignouma  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans, 7 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dibida, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe Djiguignouma qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage, font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de  grains de céréales et des condiments alimentaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 5 prêts précédents, elles  sont à leur  sixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches (petit mil, maïs, niébé, sésame) estimée à 12 sacs de 100 kg et un important stock de condiments alimentaires constitué de différentes variétés.  
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement auprès des producteurs du village et environs et des grossistes venant à la foire hebdomadaire de Fana. Elles effectuent leurs ventes dans le même marché de Fana, à domicile (au village), au comptant à crédit et en détail, à une clientèle essentiellement  composée  de revendeurs venant des grandes villes telles Bamako, Ségou et Koulikoro.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  20.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five women of the Djiguignouma group are all married. They are on average 38 years of age, have seven children, and live in traditional extended families in Dibida, one of the villages within Fana, in the Dioila Prefecture, 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They have known each other through neighborhood ties, and essentially are retailers of grain cereals and food condiments. Having correctly repaid their five previous loans, they are now requesting a sixth loan with which they will buy a large quantity (an estimated twelve 100-kilo bags) of dry cereal: millet, corn, niébé (black-eyed peas), sesame, and an important stock of various food condiments. They get their supplies mainly from local producers and from wholesalers coming to the weekly market fair in Fana. Sales are done in the same market in Fana, from their home in the village, either cash or credit and also retail, to a customer base essentially made up of retailers from large cities such as Bamako, Ségou and Koulikoro. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA each, which will be used to cover family expenses, the remainder being reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Djiguisseme  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dounamakabougou, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes  font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de céréales et de condiments alimentaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursé leur premier prêt, les femmes du groupe  Djiguisseme sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 tonnes de céréales sèches (fonio, petit mil, maïs) et une grande quantité  de condiments alimentaires telles les poivres, les oignons, les cubes maggies, les concentrées de tomates, les sels de cuisine, les sounbala.
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes au marché, au comptant, à crédit et en détail, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
NB : Oumou Sangaré est absente de la photo pour raison de santé.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguisseme are all married. They are, on average, 32 years old, have three children and live in traditional extended families in Dounamakabougou, one of the villages of Fana, in the Dioila prefecture, part of the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women mainly buy and sell cereal and condiments. After having properly repaid their first loan, the women of the Djiguisseme group are on their second joint loan which will be used to buy two tons of dry cereal (fonio, corn) and a large quantity of condiments such as peppers, onions, Maggie bouillon cubes, tomato concentrate, kitchen salt and sounbala. They mainly get their supplies in the area from producers and make their sales at the market in cash and on credit, at retail, to a clientele of men and women. They each expect to earn a monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA which will be used to meet the needs of their families, and to invest the remainder in their work. NB: Oumou Sangaré is absent from the photo due to health reasons.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase condiments

loans.name: Shurentsetseg

texts.en:
Shurentsetseg is 39 years old and lives with her husband and their two sons in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. They have been living in their current home for 15 years.  Her husband operates a transportation business. Shurentsetseg has been operating a meat retailing business since 1999.  

Shurentsetseg's business is well-known in their home province. When the business first started, its working capital was 200,000 tugrugs (~ 140 USD). However, after 11 years of hard work, Shurentsetseg's working capital has grown to 2,800,000 tugrugs (~ 1,970 USD).  Since she started the business, her family's quality of life has improved, and she has purchased a car for her family with the business profit. 

Shurentsetseg has been planning to expand her business in the future.  She is a very hard-working person and has great communication skills.  She says, “I would like to provide a good education for my children.” Shurentsetseg is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~ 2814 USD) loan to purchase large amounts of meat at wholesale prices for her business.

loans.use: To purchase large amounts of meat at wholesale prices

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les 5  femmes du groupe Djiguisseme sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 5 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dibida, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe Djiguisseme qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage, font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de  grains de céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 5 prêts précédents, elles  sont à leur  sixième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches (petit mil, maïs, niébé) estimée à 20 sacs de 100 kg. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement auprès des producteurs du village et environs et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana, à domicile,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes, d’hommes et de revendeurs venant des grandes ville telles  Bamako, Ségou et Koulikoro.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  20.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five women from the Djiguisseme group are all married. On average they are 40 years of age, have five children and live in traditional extended families in Dibida, one of the villages in Fana, Dioila Prefecture, in the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali. The women from the Djiguisseme group got acquainted through neighborhood connections, and are mainly involved in buying and selling grain cereal. Having correctly reimbursed all five preceding loans, they are now requesting a sixth group loan which they will use to buy a large quantity (estimated at twenty 100-kilo bags) of dry cereal: millet, corn, niébé (black-eyed peas). They get their supplies mainly from local producers. Sales take place at the market in Fana or from their home, usually for cash, to a customer base made up of both men and women, and retailers from large cities such as Bamako, Ségou and Koulikoro. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA each, which will be used to cover family expenses, the remainder being reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain cereal

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera owns a shop where she sells cosmetics – body sprays, lipsticks, facial powder, etc., to customers at retail prices. She started the business in the year 2005. She runs the business with the help of her two children who support her after school hours. Her younger child is 11 years old and is doing well. Her wish is to become mother of graduates in future, and she hopes to assist her husband in paying for her children’s education. Vera also provides other needs like food, clothing etc.

Vera hopes to expand and improve her business and she is requesting for a loan of NGN 80,000  She thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace W. G. is thirty-one years old, married, and has two children aged eleven and six years old, to whom they hope to give quality education. Her business is located at Mukuru kwa Njenga, an established slum business area, in Thika. 

Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. Grace has been selling electronics like DVDs, radios, televisions, etc., for the last seven years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is lack of enough working capital for the business. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 55,000 to buy more electronics to expand her business. She hopes to have many electronic shops in future. She wants to be a market leader in this business. She is very humble, respectful, and sociable.

loans.use: Electronics

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 40-year-old married man with three unemployed children. He has been working as a farmer for the past 15 years and in 1999, he opened his own business. He started cultivating all type of citrus fruits. He distributes the harvest to the agriculture market. He’s thankful for his business income because he's allowed to raise his three children.

Today, Mohamad is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase new farming merchandise such as fertilizers, seeds, and farm supplies in order to cultivate his land for the new season coming.

loans.use: To purchase new farming merchandise

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Kotognogontala  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Zanfina, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté  font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de produits alimentaires tels  les céréales,  les condiments alimentaires et le bois de chauffe.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe  Kotognogontala  sont à leur  cinquième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches (fonio, petit mil, maïs) et quelques colis de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana, à domicile,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Kotognogontala are all married. They average 36 years of age and four children each, and they live in traditional extended families in Zanfina, a village of Fana, prefecture of Dioila, 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women of the group know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they essentially buy and sell food items, such as grains and condiments, and firewood. After having properly repaid the four previous loans, the women of the group are now on their fifth solidarity loan, which will be used for buying: a large quantity of dried grains (fonio, small millet, and corn) and a few packages of condiments. Supplies are gotten locally from producers and wholesalers. Sales are made at the Fana market and at home. Cash is generally accepted from customers composed of women and men. The group members each envision making an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA that will be used to provide for the family. The rest will be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying food items

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a widow with six children. She is 60 years old and she is a grandmother. Life as a widow has been very challenging to her and the family. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She uses her years of experience in business to attract and retain more customers. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Sabaly Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Sabaly  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Zanfina, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage  font essentiellement l’achat et la vente d’articles divers tels les céréales, les condiments alimentaires et le  charbon de bois.
Après avoir correctement remboursé les quatre prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe  Sabaly  sont à leur  cinquième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches (fonio, petit mil, maïs) et quelques chargements de charrettes en charbon de  bois. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana, à domicile,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Sabaly are all married. They average 34 years of age and three children each, and they live in traditional extended families in Zanfina, a village of Fana, prefecture of Dioila, 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women of the group know one another through community ties, and they essentially buy and sell food items, such as grains and condiments, and charcoal. After having properly repaid the four previous loans, the women of the group are now on their fifth solidarity loan, which will be used for buying: a large quantity of dried grains (fonio, small millet, corn) and a few cart loads of charcoal. Supplies are gotten locally from producers. Sales are made at the Fana market and at home. Generally cash is accepted from customers composed of women and men. The group members each envision making an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA that will be used to provide for the family. The rest will be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various items

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel has owned a barbershop for the past 18 years where he services his town and the neighboring villages. Due to his long experience, he is well known in the whole region and a good number of clients visit his barbershop. He's 38 years old, married and father of two young children. 

Today, Daniel wishes to improve his barbershop and buy tools and supplies such as gel, wax, beauty products etc. to attract more customers. In order to do so, Daniel is requesting to borrow $1,200.

loans.use: To buy tools and supplies

loans.name: George

texts.en: George M. M. is twenty-nine years old, single, and has no children yet. His business is located at Hazina Estate, near the road to Nairobi. He has been selling phones, cables, and mobile accessories for the last four years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is power rationing. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 80,000 to buy a computer and a printer to expand his business. He hopes to become a millionaire in future. He is very hard-working and ambitious.

loans.use: buying a computer and a printer for his business

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Sabougnouma  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Zanfina, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté  font essentiellement l’achat et la vente de produits alimentaires  tels  les grains de céréales  et  les condiments alimentaires.
Ces femmes du groupe Sabougnouma  sont à leur  premier  prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches ( petit mil, maïs) et un important stock de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana, à domicile,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 9.000FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Sabougnouma are all married. They average 38 years of age and four children each, and they live in traditional extended families in Zanfina, a village of Fana, prefecture of Dioila, 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women of the group know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they essentially buy and sell food items, such as grains and condiments. The women of the group are now on their first solidarity loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They intend to use this loan to buy a large quantity of dried grains (pearl millet, corn) and a major stock of condiments. Supplies are gotten essentially from producers and wholesalers. Sales are made at the Fana market and at home. Generally cash is accepted from customers composed of women and men. The group members each envision making an average monthly profit of 9,000 francs CFA that will be used to provide for the family. The rest will be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying food items

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna is a petty trader. She sells yams, clothes, and shoes to make a living. She hopes to be a major foodstuffs distributor in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 30,000 to purchase more yams to sell. She is married to a bricklayer and they are blessed with 2 children. Anna’s children are schooling and they are excelling in their school work. She hopes to see her children graduate from the university in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more yams to sell

loans.name: Yeredeme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Yeredeme  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Zanfina, un des villages de Fana, préfecture de Dioila, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes du groupe qui se sont connus à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté  font essentiellement l’achat et la vente d’articles divers tels  les céréales, le charbon de bois, le bois de chauffe  et  les condiments alimentaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursé leur premier prêt, les femmes du groupe Yeredeme  sont à leur  deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de grains de céréales sèches ( petit mil, maïs etc.), quelques paquets de condiments alimentaires et 35 sacs de charbon de bois. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Fana, à domicile,  généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75.00FCFA qui sera  utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Yeredeme are all married. They average 34 years of age and three children each, and they live in traditional extended families in Zanfina, a village of Fana, prefecture of Dioila, 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women of the group know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they essentially buy and sell food items, such as grains, charcoal, firewood, and condiments. After having properly repaid their first loan, the women of the group are now on their second solidarity loan, which will be used for buying: a large quantity of dried grains (pearl millet, corn, etc.), a few packages of condiments, and 35 sacks of charcoal. Supplies are gotten locally from producers and wholesalers. Sales are made at the Fana market and at home. Generally cash is accepted from customers composed of women and men. The group members each envision making an average monthly profit of 7,500 francs CFA that will be used to provide for the family. The rest will be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various items

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a 51-year-old single woman living with her mother only. She has owned a mini-market in her town since 2008. She opened this small business and she works hard to earn income to help her old mother and take care of her.  Her shop is situated in a busy area, so she has been able to have a growing number of customers pass by her shop. 

Today, Mariam is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to fill her shop with additionA. merchandise like food products, drinks, cereals, etc., to meet the demand of her customers and gain new ones.

loans.use: fill her shop with additional merchandise

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 42 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à N’Tjifina sous préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des condiments alimentaires et de l’arachide.
Ces femmes du groupe Djekafo viennent de commencer leur collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance avec qui, elles sont à leur  premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des paquets de condiments alimentaires et des sacs d’arachide.
Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments le plus généralement à Fana et l’arachide est acheté dans les environs du village. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Nangola, Fana et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women from the Djekafo group are all married with an average age of 42 and on average four children. They all live in traditional extended families in N’Tjifina sub-prefecture of Dioïla, region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of Mali). They know one another through ties of kinship and sell condiments and peanuts. These women from the Djekafo group just began their collaboration with the microfinance institution. This is their first group loan that will be used to buy packs of condiments and bags of peanuts. They source their condiments from Fana and the peanuts are bought in the vicinity of the village. They sell their goods at the Nangola and Fana markets and at the large fairs in the area. They sell for cash or on credit to customers who are women and men. They each are planning to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 Francs CFA which will be used for the daily family expenses and reinvested in the business’ s activities.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments and peanuts.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Toyin sells drinks and foodstuffs. She buys in large quantity and sells retail. She does this business to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 45 years old, a widow, and has three children. She hopes to expand the size of her business so she can make more sales and profit. She said this will enable her to train up her fatherless children.

Toyin is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She promises to repay the loan promptly. She expresses her gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria is 50 years old and married with 8 children. Her husband is a bricklayer and he also supports their home. Gloria sells second-hand clothes, shoes and bags at retail prices. Demand for the second-hand clothes is high in her community among those who cannot afford new clothes. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 30,000 to purchase more second-hand clothes, shoes and bags to sell. She is itching for expansion in her business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes, shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha N. K. is thirty-eight years old. She is single and has no children yet. Her business is located at Riverbank Estate in Nairobi, Kenya. She has been doing printing services for students and Riverbank Estate residents for the last five years. She also does photocopy and computer training. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is not so many customers as the business is restricted to Estate customers. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Tabitha is using her loan of Kes 60,000 to buy a photocopier and a computer to expand her business. In future, she hopes to open her own big computer training institutite. She is a very hard-working, humble but ambitious lady.

loans.use: buying a photocopier and a computer

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kotognontala, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 37 ans,  6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à N’Tjifina sous préfecture de Fana,  Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce  de céréales, des condiments, de l’arachide et de poissons.
Les femmes du groupe Kotognontala sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des condiments, des céréales, des poissons et de l’arachide.
Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments tantôt à Bamako tantôt à Fana et sur place pour les autres produits. Elles effectuent leurs ventes sur place et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women from the Kotognontala group are all married. On average they are 37 years of age, have 6 children and all live in traditional extended families in N’Tjifina in the Fana Sub-Prefecture of the Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They were acquainted through family connections and are in the business of retailing grain cereals, food condiments, peanuts and fish. This is the first group loan request for the Kotognontala group, which will be used to buy condiments, grain cereals, fish and peanuts. They get the condiments from Bamako or Fana, and the other products locally. They sell locally and in area market fairs, retail, cash or credit, to both men and women customers. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 25,000 FCFA each, which will be used to cover healthcare needs, nourishment, school expenses, the remainder being reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain cereals, food condiments, fish and peanuts

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is always happy. She says that happiness enables her to attract and retain more customers. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. 

Joy hopes for the loan amount of NGN 30,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. Joy is 35 years old and married with 4 children. Her husband is a petty trader and he also supports their home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Leila

texts.en:
Leila is a 49-year-old married woman and mother of 2 children. She has owned a toys and accessories shop since 2006 to help her husband with the family income. And her children have also started working and they are trying to cooperate with them as a family. 

Today, Leila is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy more toys and accessories for her shop before the holidays to attract more customers and increase her sales and thus her income.

loans.use: buy more toys and accessories

loans.name: Kounadia Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kounadia, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 42 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à N’Tjifina sous préfecture de Fana,  Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des condiments alimentaires, des céréales et des habillements.   
Ces femmes du groupe Kounadia sont à leur premier prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des  paquets de condiments alimentaires, des céréales et des habits pour  hommes et femmes.
Elles s’approvisionnent généralement en habillements et condiments à Bamako et dans le village en céréales avec les producteurs et les grossistes sur place. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes au marché de la ville de Fana, Nangola et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
